outcomes.description: The River Burl runs backwards for a day, in defiance of winds and tides.
All the coffee in Endon turns to water. All coffee beans turn to small ice cubes.
For a week, sparrows catch fire and fly into windows.
It rains upwards for a few hours. Puddles roil and sizzle as small droplets leap skyward.
A large statue of a gryphon stamps its claw three times every day at noon.
A raven the size of a cottage lands on the Parliament of Endon (3, pg. 9). It flies away if threatened but returns every night.
Spiders spell out mathematical equations in their webs. None of the equations make any sense. Mathematicians and entomologists are amused but slightly worried.
Musical instruments in Endon fling themselves out of tune. Musicians slowly adjust them, but some will never be the same again. All concerts temporarily cancelled.
All mirrors show slightly incorrect things approximately 50% of the time. Reflections sport new scars and hair colours. Some are delayed, some are sped up.
Children report the same dreams. Every night, all they can hear and imagine is the sea.
For a full day, everyone is unable to recall their own name or the names of anyone else.
All horses flee towards the River Burl, leaping off bridges and drowning themselves, dragging carriages and carts with them. Horses that are restrained batter themselves to exhaustion.
A comet with three tails is seen over the city for several nights. It is only visible within the city limits but the astrologers assure everyone this is perfectly normal.
Clouds passing over Endon form unnatural geometric shapes: smooth-sided pyramids, long cylinders, tumbling octahedrons.
An entire neighborhood vanishes. All the maps are also altered, but everyone remembers it. Just south of Haymarket Square (6, pg. 9)... right? And what happened to the people?
All rubies in Endon become cloudy, like dried blood.
For a full day, books and ledgers in Endon fly open, as if an invisible ghostly giant was racing through the city and ransacking libraries.
For a week, gravity alters half a degree to the northeast. Things slowly slide off tables, people trip over stairs and endlessly fuss over hanging pictures.
Coins featuring the Monarchâ€™s face refuse to land face-side up if tossed. They can be flipped over with a slight effort.
Interest in one of the Eight Deadly Sins (1d8, pg. 60) spikes to ludicrous levels for a full day.
